definition[0]: a genuine feeling, desire etc is one that you really feel, not one you pretend to feel
example[0]: ‘Did he really?’ Her surprise seemed genuine.
example[1]: The reforms are motivated by a genuine concern for the disabled.
definition[1]: something genuine really is what it seems to be
example[3]: We need laws that will protect genuine refugees.
definition[2]: someone who is genuine is honest and friendly and you feel you can trust them
example[5]: She is the most genuine person I’ve ever met.
definition[3]: used about a feeling, thing, or person that really is what they seem to be
example[7]: Experts believe that the painting is genuine.
example[9]: a genuine reason for taking time off work
example[10]: If a student has genuine religious objections to a school activity, they do not have to participate.
example[13]: It looks just like the real thing.
example[14]: Are those flowers real or artificial?
definition[5]: authentic  food, music, clothes etc are correct for the place or the period in history that they are supposed to be from
example[15]: It’s a friendly restaurant offering authentic Greek food.
example[17]: The dancers wore authentic Native American designs.
definition[6]: having all the qualities you would expect a particular type of person or thing to have
example[20]: Being a true Red Sox fan, he never missed a game.
example[21]: True Christians believe that Jesus is the Son of God.
definition[7]: bona fide people or things are really what they say they are, especially when this can be checked by looking at official documents
example[24]: This club is only open to bona fide members.
definition[8]: evidence or facts that are genuine and can be proved
example[25]: There was no hard evidence to support the theory.
